title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DALLAS (AP) — On a night where offense was a precious commodity, Hakeem Olajuwon authored a defensive masterpiece for the ages. The Houston Rockets’ 88-83 victory over the Dallas Mavericks was not merely a win; it was a one-man clinic, a testament to the sheer dominance of "The Dream" at the absolute peak of his powers.

While his game-high 24 points was impressive, it was the unfathomable final line next to his name that told the true story: **10 blocked shots**. Olajuwon didn’t just patrol the paint; he erected a fortress around it, swatting away Maverick attempts with a breathtaking combination of timing, grace, and ferocity. Dallas guards driving the lane met the same fate as their big men in the post—rejection and frustration.

The Mavericks, led by a gritty 21-point effort from Jim Jackson, found moments of daylight, but any semblance of rhythm was shattered by Olajuwon’s omnipresent arms. His 10 blocks, a staggering defensive stat, demoralized the home team and fueled the Rockets’ transition game, allowing Clyde Drexler to chip in 18 points despite an otherwise cold shooting night for Houston.

In a grind-it-out defensive battle where both teams struggled to crack 90 points, Olajuwon’s presence was the ultimate decider. He was the Rockets' offense, their defense, and their backbone. This was not a game won by a team, but by a singular, historic force of nature. On this night in Dallas, Hakeem Olajuwon didn’t just beat the Mavericks; he utterly erased them.
